Comment: The 19 degrees of graphite pencil hardness are: 14B, 12B, 10B, 8B, 7B, 6B, 5B, 4B, 3B, 2B, B, HB, F, H, 2H, 3H, 4H, 5H, and 6H.   Source: Faber-Castell  No, I will not be posting pictures of my pencil case.
Author: 1984isAMidlifeCrisis

Comment: It's a designation of the hardness of a graphite pencil.  Traditional (non-digital) artists use them to get a very wide range. Another comment gave a good example of the range.  The ones with a 'B' are softer & darker.  The ones with 'H' are harder & lighter.  Pencil artists end up with a lot of them since you normally wear through some quicker than others.  A basic set of these are considered a required supply in most foundational art classes and they're already very expensive.  Supply costs are often a roadblock to children really getting into traditional art.  As for the colored pencils bit... colored pencil artists (even just hobbyists) will often have hundreds (if not thousands) of pencils in every shade imaginable, and actually do need a huge range to make the art they do.    In both cases, the cheap version of these pencils often are already broken or a very poor quality to the point of just frustrating learners.  If the most reliable brands are priced out of reach, or if someone in power truly doesn't understand why that many are needed, fine arts are going to suffer even more than they already are.  Availability is already a challenge in some areas, and they don't ship particularly well as some have very fragile lead.  Even with the move to largely digital art, most of these artists still had foundational art classes or self instruction using these traditional mediums because they teach foundational & observational skills and help develop the fine motor control needed.
